(d) the war against want requires to be carried on with unrelenting vigour within each nation, and by continuous and concerted international effort in which the representatives of workers and employers, enjoying equal status with those of governments join with them in free discussion and democratic decision with a view to the promotion of the common welfare."

I think it is clear from that that the ILO is a internationally respected organisation that is looking at key issues with respect to the overall wellbeing of the world, and in that respect it is deserving of strong support. The situation has been that there has been strong support for the ILO both within Australia and also internationally.

PARA.TAB: Within Australia we have had a situation where coalition governments have ratified 22 of the 54 conventions ratified by Australia, including several important ones: No. 42, regarding workers compensation; No. 47, the 40-hour week; No. 88, employment service; No. 105, abolition of forced labour; No. 122, employment policy; No. 123, minimum age, underground work; and No. 144, tripartite consultation and international labour standards. Labor governments have ratified 32.

There was a motion in the House of Representatives on 7 December 1994 on the issue of the 75th anniversary of the ILO. That motion received bipartisan support of the House. I would like to quote from the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who spoke on behalf of the opposition in that debate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the ILO has performed a very valuable service and is a very respected organisation in world social and equity terms.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) also spoke in that debate. He raised the issue of several international plaudits that had been received by the ILO. One was on the occasion of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the ILO in 1969. The Chairman of the Nobel Committee said:

There are few organisations that have succeeded, to the extent that the ILO has succeeded, in translating into action the fundamental moral idea on which it is based. . . Working earnestly and untiringly, the ILO has succeeded in introducing reforms that have removed the most flagrant injustices in a great many countries. . .

His Holiness Pope John Paul II gave an audience to the chairman of the ILO governing body in 1992. He also congratulated the ILO for putting social dialogue and tripartite cooperation at the forefront of its considerations. President Nelson Mandela, in contributing to a volume of essays entitled Visions of the Future of Social Justice on the occasion on the ILO's 75th anniversary, wrote:

The present situation in South Africa, where a majority of the population is trying to rectify the experience of generations of systematic exclusion from the most basic rights and benefits, highlights the ongoing relevance of the ILO mandate. Many South Africans are only now recognising that lasting peace can be established only on the basis of social justice, 75 years after it was expounded as the founding principle of the ILO.
The circumstances around ILO conventions are to some extent different from some other international treaties. ILO conventions are based on a partnership approach.

PARA.TAB: There is, as I mentioned earlier, a tripartite structure: representatives of employers and workers have equal voting rights with governments in the various ILO forums. The ILO constitution requires employer and worker representatives to participate in ILO processes. They caucus separately from each other and from governments, and vote according to the agreement of their groups. Australian employers and workers are represented by the peak bodies, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

International labour standards are instruments which comprise either conventions, which are open to ratification, or recommendations, which simply provide guidelines to governments. These are adopted by the ILO conference, usually after a double discussion process, whereby the topic is discussed at two successive sessions of the ILO conference. Prior to each ILO conference discussion, the ILO produces a report which analyses responses to a questionnaire. These reports form the basis of discussion. The Australian government responses to questionaries and briefs to delegates, are prepared after consultation with the states and territories, the ACCI and the ACTU.

The fact that a member supports the adoption of a convention at the ILO conference has no impact on the obligations of that member. The decision to ratify is made independently of the vote to adopt. This is a very important issue with respect to our actions on international conventions. Quite often I have had constituents raise with me the fact that we are a signatory to an agreement, or that we have supported some other agreement in an international forum. What that really means with respect to Australian law and to Australian society may be quite different to what is often assumed.

When we are talking about some conventions, we are talking about broad statements of principle which have a certain amount of flexibility within them, in order to take into account the particular conditions which may be faced within a particular member state. In those circumstances, the seriousness of a particular issue may well be overstated by a purely literal reading or literal reporting of what has occurred.

As I said earlier, Australian delegations attending the ILO conference comprise government, employer and worker representatives. They work in concert with their own groups. The government delegation includes state or territory representatives, in accordance with an agreed order of attendance. This is funded by the Commonwealth government in recognition of the important role played by state and territory governments in implementing ILO conventions.

As the previous speaker, the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), commented, the circumstances of the detail of the convention and how it may work, if adjusted into law, is such that the role of state governments in the implementation process is often crucial. There has to be that involvement from a state and territory basis as well—that what is in the end ratified and in the end adopted is something which is workable within the various state systems that we have within this federal system.

The state or territory minister for labour and the opposition spokespersons on industrial relations are invited to attend the ILO conference for the same time as the Minister for Industrial Relations. Again, this is funded by the Commonwealth. It is usual Australian practice not to ratify an ILO convention unless two conditions are met: firstly, that law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions comply with its provisions; and, secondly, that all relevant state and territory governments have formally agreed to ratification. The caveat of `relevant' is included because some conventions fall within the Commonwealth's jurisdiction alone. There is also a third precondition—the formal agreement of the ACCI and the ACTU.

The ILO conference adopted convention No. 176 concerning safety and health in mines in June 1995. As I mentioned earlier, of the 176 ILO conventions, Australia has, at this stage, ratified 54. A further three conventions dealing with employment conditions for seafarers are expected to be ratified soon. Ratification of these conventions is significant in that it will help Australia achieve compliance with convention No. 147 with respect to merchant shipping minimum standards.

So often you can have a situation where a number of conventions have to fit together—to lock in—to actually meet the conditions of another convention but, essentially, it is about trying to improve the overall safety net, often in a particular area of conditions with respect to workers as a whole or with respect to a particular industry. Obviously, the merchant marine industry, as an international industry, is a key industry for the ILO to have an interest in.

I mentioned earlier the question of ILO conventions versus other treaties. The significant aspect of state consultations on ILO conventions compared to other treaties is that it is ongoing. The ILO conference is an annual event and the processes are well established. The requirement of federal member states to consult with their constituent states is unique in the United Nations system, as is the direct involvement of the social partners in the development of international labour standards and the ratification process.

In the context of its inquiry into treaties, the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee appeared to be impressed by the consultative processes for ILO conventions as described by the Department of Industrial Relations. Senator Ellison, the chair of the committee, and Senator Kemp both suggested that the ILO processes might comprise a model for all treaties.

As part of that overall debate on the question of treaties and external affairs and the way that the government operates with respect to those particular issues, there has been a range of debates. A number of issues were raised by Senator Abetz as a member of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. Senator Abetz criticised the government for consulting with peak groups rather than constituent groups and individuals within the community.

Essentially, in the circumstances of ILO conventions, we are required by the terms of the ILO constitution and convention No. 144 on tripartite consultation to deal with the most representative organisation of employers and workers. The point is often made that the ACTU is not fully representative of the needs and aspirations of workers in this country. The figures on the membership of unions and the particular areas that they actually are involved in with respect to employment within Australia are raised but, again, the question is: if you don't consult with them, who do you consult with? The nature of government, the need to actually involve aspects of the community but at the same time reach decisions over time, requires government to make choices and, in those circumstances, the ACTU certainly is the most appropriate body with respect to employees.

The same circumstances relate to the question of employers. The ACCI, in its own way, is not ideal with respect to this issue but it is, in fact, the best option that is available under the circumstances if you wish to consult with the employer sector about what employers see as being important in terms of any particular conventions that may be under consideration.

Issues were also raised by Senator Abetz regarding, for example, Vietnam as a nation which should pay greater regard to the standards that we employ in Australia. One of the things that the government has tried to do through the ILO is to provide assistance to Vietnam in this regard by helping to translate key ILO conventions into Vietnamese and by assisting with the development of their newly adopted labour code and to improve action on the ILO conventions within that country. I commend the paper to the House. I think it has a lot of valuable information which can be used in the future in the consideration of conventions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks in the context of the tabling of this paper on ILO conventions in Australia relate to the shipping industry, particularly ILO 147. Some members will recall our Ships of shame report that was tabled in December of 1992 and, in particular, what it said about conditions for crew members. We highlighted the exploitation, impoverishment and straight-out physical abuse that was being perpetrated upon crew members, particularly crew members from Third World countries.

PARA.TAB: In that report we made a recommendation that the government not permit vessels to enter Australian ports if they could not prove that they were complying with ILO 147. The text of recommendation 11 was that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government deny entry to ships which do not meet ILO 147 standards in relation to crew employment conditions from trading in Australian waters.
The response of the government was to say that:
It is not feasible to assess whether a ship complies with ILO 147 standards prior to inspection—
referring to port state inspection—

which can only be carried out in port. The present system which provides for detention of non-compliant ships until deficiencies are rectified is therefore considered the most appropriate approach to ensuring that conditions on board ships are not hazardous to safety and/or the health of their crews.

Our committee carried out a further review of ship safety and the matters relating to crew conditions. It presented to the parliament in November of last year a progress report in which we looked at the responses from government and industry to the recommendations that we had made. We will present a final report to the parliament at the end of the coming November.

PARA.TAB: Having looked at the responses of the government, industry, ship operators, ship managers and ship owners, as a committee we remain more convinced than ever that ILO 147 should be ratified by this country and that we should be demanding proof of compliance with ILO 147 before ships are allowed to enter Australian ports.

We were told that it was very difficult to ensure that a ship was meeting ILO 147 conditions before the ship came into the port, as I mentioned a few minutes ago. That is not nearly as difficult as it seems or as it is described in those words. There is always the last port state inspection that the vessel has been subjected to. Information is always available on the reputation and standard of management of the ship concerned, and information will increasingly be transmitted from port state inspections around the world through the various port state groupings, particularly the Asia-Pacific port state group.

For some time we have been exchanging information about conditions on board ships and the condition of ships so that when a ship and/or its treatment of crew is substandard that information can be transmitted ahead of the ship's arrival to the appropriate port state inspection group. In Australia's case, that is the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

Members may wonder why we are so concerned about ILO 147. It is the international convention that protects employment, accommodation and treatment of crews on board ships. Those who have read our Ships of shame report or have been in any way involved with some of the substandard ships that come into Australian ports will well understand. Twenty countries ratified the principal convention, ILO 147, and it had been declared applicable to 18 non-metropolitan territories. These 38 countries covered 45 per cent of the world shipping gross tonnage.

The convention involves a commitment to safety standards. From our examination of the shipping industry, the conditions, morale, care and accommodation all have a bearing on the crews' ability to carry out their tasks on board ship, the competency with which that vessel is operating and therefore on the safety of the vessel. So the convention involves a commitment to safety standards, social security measures and established shipboard conditions of employment and living conditions. The standards under ILO 147 should be substantially equivalent to the articles that are covered in the detail of the convention.

Effective jurisdiction or control needs to be exercised over home registered vessels—that is vessels registered under the flag of the nation concerned. There must be adequate procedures for the employment of seafarers. Seafarers must be properly qualified and adequately trained. Maritime labour standards must be enforced, principally by inspection, and there should be an inquiry into any serious marine casualty. Advice should be provided to nationals and states which have ratified the convention on the problems of working on a vessel flagged in a state which has not ratified the convention. Port states may take action to rectify clearly hazardous deficiencies on board and may notify the country of registration.

Recommendation 155, which is an adjunct to ILO convention 147, proposes the continued extension of the list of what should be considered minimum labour standards in merchant shipping and improvement in national provisions to reach a standard which is at least equivalent to specified requirements under ILO 147. In response to our recommendations, the government has said, `Whilst we have not ratified ILO 147, we are implementing the spirit of ILO 147 through marine orders via the inspection authority—the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. So, whilst we have not formally ratified the convention, we are carrying out those tasks we would be carrying out had we ratified the convention.'

We do not accept that that is good enough. The abuse that takes place on some ships coming into Australian ports is incredible. It is something that we were appalled by as a committee. We continue to be appalled by it, and it is something that none of us expected to find. For example, when we looked at the accommodation conditions we found the following: no hot water, one toilet amongst many seafarers, no lighting, water dribbling through the cabins, inadequate food, and crews being starved. One could go on and on about the details of the abuses that take place.

In this scenario, Australia has to be a leader, not a follower. The ships that have these kinds of conditions on board and the nations under which these ships are flagged are well known. We now call them `flags of shame'. The ships of shame are the substandard ships, and the nations which perpetrate these abuses, or which allow these abuses to be perpetrated on ships flying their flags, are flags of shame. The owners of the freight have to accept public responsibility, they have to accept public accountability for the treatment that is being meted out to these crew members.

ILO 147 is a good convention. It needs to be ratified. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) said, in response to the report, that the government was implementing the spirit of the convention, but that there had to be agreement among the states. We have not had agreement among all the states. There are three other ILO maritime conventions that we are proposing to ratify on the adoption of a statutory definition of seagoing vessels, which would ensure that their implementation depended on Commonwealth compliance alone. Those three other conventions are: convention 145, `Continuity of Employment (Seafarers)', 1976; convention 146, `Seafarers' Annual Leave with Pay', 1976; and convention 147, `Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards)', 1976—which is the one I am referring to.

It is not good enough for the industry to go quietly—and here we are talking about shippers, exporters and importers—and benefit from these kinds of abuses and for the government to say, `Well, we haven't yet got the states' agreement on all of these matters, but when we do then we could proceed with it.' What we are being advised at the moment is that the Department of Transport is considering a proposal from the Department of Industrial Relations which suggests that the Commonwealth complies with convention 147.

There are two areas which require examination. Apart from the Commonwealth loan implementation question, the Commonwealth needs to demonstrate compliance or substantial equivalence with one of three social security conventions appended to ILO 147. In light of the amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 made in conjunction with the adoption of the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993, the Department of Industrial Relations suggests that section 127, which addresses shipowners' liability for medical attendants, et cetera, complies with convention 55, which is shipowners' liability for sick and injured seamen. Compliance with conventions 145 and 146 is based on federal industrial awards.

The National Labour Consultative Council agreed in March 1988 that ILO maritime conventions should be considered in a tripartite consultative forum in the transport portfolio and the Department of Industrial Relations is asking Transport to initiate consultation with the relevant body. The Maritime Services Advisory Committee has carried out this function in the past.

The states and the Northern Territory have been invited to comment on the proposal to ratify these three conventions on the basis of Commonwealth law and practice alone. So far, Victoria, Western Australia and the Northern Territory have supported the proposal. Given that the states have agreed to a similar proposal with respect to conventions 69 and 73, we do not anticipate that there will be any concerns raised.

The final position is that, once there is agreement from the social partners and the states and the territories that ratification may take place on the basis of Commonwealth compliance alone, once the Department of Transport agrees that compliance can be demonstrated with ILO convention 147 and once the Department of the Attorney-General certifies compliance, ratification of these three conventions may be possible. It is a long voyage that we are embarked upon. We will be looking at this matter again in the coming weeks as we conclude our review of ship safety. The convention imposes obligations on Australia in relation to loss of life and injury and the conditions under which ship crews work.

There is a lot said about casualties at sea. I want to tell the committee that safety at sea is the basis of the international convention. There is no systematic recording of data on deaths and injuries. It seems from all of our research—and that is confirmed abroad—that the only seamen who appear to be counted are those who go down with their ship. So if you want to be counted in marine casualty statistics around the world then you have to go down to the bottom. If you are injured on board, maimed or hurt on board, there is no mechanism for recording those casualties. That is another major defect in the system. It is all revolving around ILO convention 147.

We recommended in November 1994 that the Commonwealth government take action to ratify ILO convention 147. We still adhere to our earlier recommendation that the government not permit vessels that cannot provide proof of compliance with ILO 147 to enter Australian ports and to enter Australian waters. We feel very strongly about this. I know that the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), as a member of the committee, has very similar views. It is difficult to track down the owners and the managers of vessels. It is difficult in Australia to do other than ensure that before the vessel leaves port it does meet international maritime safety standards.

I want to give notice that we will be pursuing much more strongly the beneficiaries of those abuses on ships because at the end of the day, they are the people who have to stand up and say, `Yes, we know what is going on. Yes, we use that ship with those abuses on that ship because we get a cheap rate from them.' That is the accountability. That is the responsibility that has to come much more to public notice.

I bring that information before the committee because it is a matter about which we as a committee feel very strongly. It is Australia that has been giving a lead around the world in this major area of the improvement of ship safety.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hills Motorway Prospectus—Involvement of Australian Securities Commission and Attorney-General

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on I June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his or the Australian Securities Commission's (ASC) attention been drawn to a prospectus issued by Hills Motorway Trust and The Hills Motorway Limited in 1994 seeking funds from the public to invest in the construction and operation of Sydney's M2 motorway project.

(2) Has his or the ASC's attention been drawn to: (a) the performance audit report of the New South Wales Auditor-General on the Roads and Traffic Authority and the M2 motorway dated 3 1 January 1995 and (b) a document prepared by independent consultant R.J. Tanner entitled Motorway : Hills Motorway Trust, The Hills Motorway Limited, A financial analysis of operations after construction dated 4 April 1995; if so, do these analyses show significant discrepancies with the traffic flow estimated relied on by the prospectus.

(3) Has the ASC investigated claims (a) by an independent analyst that the prospectus provides sensitivity analysis and pre-tax internal-rate-of-return analysis commencing at a level of average daily traffic volume that project consultants acknowledge are unlikely to be attained and, (b) that the conclusions of the prospectus rely on a report prepared by consultants who were paid $1.2 million by the contractors for project design work thus compromising the consultants' independence; if so, what are the results of the investigations; if not, will he cause the claims to be investigated.
(4) What action (a) can be taken and (b) will he cause to be taken to protect investors if the failure of the prospectus to meet the relevant requirements causes them to suffer losses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I am advised that on 17 November 1994 the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) registered the prospectus issued by the Hills Motorway Limited and the Hills Motorway Trust, dated 7 November 1994, in accordance with the section 1020A of the Corporations Law. Section 1020A of the Corporations Law requires the ASC to register a prospectus within 14 days unless it appears that the prospectus does not comply with the Corporations Law, or the ASC forms the opinion that the prospectus contains a false or misleading statement or that there is a material omission. The Attorney-General has no role in the registration of prospectuses and accordingly, I have no detailed knowledge of the Hills Motorway prospectus.

(2) (a) The ASC advises that the NSW's Auditor-General's performance audit of 31 January 1995 has been drawn to its attention and it is of the view that the audit raised no new issues that warranted ASC action.

(b) I am advised that the ASC has been provided with the document prepared by R J Tanner entitled Motorway : Hills Motorway Trust, The Hills Motorway Limited, A financial analysis of operations after construction dated 4 April 1995 and has reviewed that report in the context of other reports made available to the ASC. The ASC advises that the analysis of R J Tanner diverged in a number of respects from the projections in the prospectus. I am further advised that the ASC is unable to comment on the likelihood of any particular set of projections being achieved and seeks to satisfy itself, on the basis of its inquiries, that any forecasts or projections would appear to have a reasonable basis. On the basis of the information provided and after consideration of the circumstances in which those reports were obtained, the ASC formed the view that there appeared to be a reasonable basis for the forecasts in the prospectus in relation to traffic volumes and potential rates of return.

(3)(a) I am advised that the ASC conducted inquiries into the projections in the prospectus during the offer period. The ASC has subsequently considered the report of R J Tanner in the light of those earlier inquiries and a number of experts' reports. The ASC advises that it does not attempt to resolve differences between projections made in a prospectus and those made by some other party provided the projections in the prospectus appear to have been made on a reasonable basis.

(b) I am advised that the payment to the traffic expert, Gutteridge, Haskins and Davey Pty Ltd, who provided project design work for the Hills Motorway project, was disclosed in the prospectus. After consideration of the circumstances in which the original report was provided, the circumstances of the payment and other reports known to the directors, I am advised that the ASC decided not to pursue any further action at that time.

(4)(a) Under the Corporations Law investors have statutory rights of action to recover, for any loss or damage that they may suffer, against persons involved in the preparation of the prospectus, including directors who signed the prospectus and experts who consented to the inclusion of their reports in the prospectus, where statements in the prospectus prove to be false or misleading, or there is a material omission from the prospectus.

(b) I am advised that the ASC will continue to monitor the performance of the project in light of the information contained in the prospectus and will take any action considered appropriate, should the circumstances arise. Therefore, I do not propose to direct the ASC to investigate the matter. As stated in my answer to question 4(a), remedies are available to investors under the Corporations Law for loss or damage suffered where statements in a prospectus prove to be false or misleading or there is a material omission from the prospectus.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he able to say how many authorised phone taps have been made by the Western Australian Police Force in each year since 1988.
(2) For what purposes are phone taps authorised.
(3) Who is responsible for the technical aspects of installing the necessary listening devices for authorised phone taps.
(4) Does the Commonwealth ensure that the Western Australian Police Force does not engage in unauthorised phone tapping; if so, how.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) None, the Western Australian Police Force is not an intercepting agency for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
(2) Not applicable
(3) Not applicable

(4) To the extent it is possible to police such matters, the Commonwealth relies on the carriers to inform it of any unauthorised interceptions they detect. Any such matter would be referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation.
